attributes.title: Pre-analysis plan: Are voters difference-in-differences estimators? Evidence from experimentally benchmarking recent and longer-term municipal homicide rates in Mexico

q1.value: Pre-analysis plan: Are voters difference-in-differences estimators? Evidence from experimentally benchmarking recent and longer-term municipal homicide rates in Mexico

q5.value: This project received financial support from the Columbia Summer Research Support Program for Humanities and Social Sciences and the Columbia Lenfest Junior Faculty Development Grant.

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Political accountability is generally regarded as being a central pillar ensuring good governance and its socioeconomic benefits. However, and particularly in developing contexts where governance is weakest, holding politicians to account is challenging for many voters due to their lack of useful information about the actions of their representatives in office. Building on a variety of recent studies examining the effects of information dissemination on electoral, this study focuses on the types of incumbent performance information that influence voters, differentiating recent and longer-term performance and different types of performance benchmark.

q16.value: I seek to estimate the effects of providing recent v. longer-term information about municipal homicide outcomes on incumbent appraisals and electoral support. To examine the relevance of different types of benchmark, I will compare providing information about each homicide metric with (i) a spatial benchmark (average neighboring municipal administration), (ii) a temporal benchmark (the previous municipal administration), or (iii) a difference-in-differences benchmark. A variety of questions are designed to establish whether the information was understood and illuminate the mechanisms underlying any treatment effects.

q17.value: Field experiment randomizing the provision of text-based and infographic municipal homicide data as part of a panel survey conducted around the 2018 Mexican elections. There are 10 treatment conditions, including a pure control, placebo control, 4 factorial benchmarks relating to recent homicide information, and 4 factorial benchmarks relating to longer-term homicide rates under the current municipal administration.

registration_responses.q1: Pre-analysis plan: Are voters difference-in-differences estimators? Evidence from experimentally benchmarking recent and longer-term municipal homicide rates in Mexico
registration_responses.q5: This project received financial support from the Columbia Summer Research Support Program for Humanities and Social Sciences and the Columbia Lenfest Junior Faculty Development Grant.

attributes.title: Tracking Hope in Nairobi and Karachi: Testing Educational Assumptions (THINK)

q1.value: Tracking Hope in Nairobi and Karachi: Testing Educational Assumptions (THINK)

q2.value: Elisabeth King | Dana Burde | Jennifer Hill | Daphna Harel

q9.value: Registration as the process that serves as the determination of treatment is ongoing. The start date below reflects earliest determination (first university Pakistan; others in progress). The Kenya determination began in Feb 2018 and is ongoing.

q15.value: Large youth populations feature prominently in discussions of threats to social and state stability worldwide. Scant empirical research investigates the causal relationship between educational access and positive or negative attitudes and behaviors in youth. This study entails a rigorous testing of the effect of access and non-access to tertiary education in Karachi, Pakistan, and Nairobi, Kenya. We ask (1) whether educational access affects hope; (2) whether educational access affects attitudes and behaviors conducive to peace or conflict; and (3) whether these relationships work through hope or hopelessness, concepts frequently invoked in the global discourse surrounding youth and violence. Primarily through use of a quantitative survey, we will compare youth whose aspirations for access to education are fulfilled with those whose aspirations are blocked at three points in time: (1) as applications to university are submitted during their final year of secondary school (2) soon after the release of university admissions decisions , and (3) one year after the release. In so doing, we will systematically and quantitatively map the trajectory of youth outcomes as they experience success or failure in their educational goals, thereby illuminating whether educational access or non-access affects hope, and peace and conflict attitudes and behaviors.

q16.value: Our primary hypotheses focus on the most basic questions that we can address with the most rigorous designs/methods. Therefore the primary hypotheses to be tested focus on the effect of university access (as defined in our pre-analysis plan) and are the following: 1. University access has an effect on hope; 2. University access has an effect on attitudes and behaviors conducive to peace or conflict. Given that the relevant literature on these relationships has conflicting theories about their directionality, and little previous research has been performed to confirm or reject these theories, we do not propose directionality in our hypotheses. We are also interested in hypotheses about the effect of university attendance on our outcomes as well as the relationship between hope and our outcomes. Answering these questions will require making additional assumptions (as described in our pre-analysis plan) so we consider them to be secondary hypotheses. The secondary hypotheses to be tested are the following: 1. University attendance has an effect on hope; 2. University attendance has an effect on attitudes and behaviors conducive to peace or conflict; 3. Hope is associated with subsequent attitudes and behaviors conducive to peace or conflict. Analyses targeting other quantities of interest, including subgroup effects, will be considered exploratory.

q17.value: These causal relationships will be tested by capitalizing on naturally-occurring regression discontinuity designs that are created by the university admissions processes in each country. Although the overarching research design is conceptually similar across the two countries, differences between how admission tests are used in Kenya versus Pakistan will lead to slightly different designs in each country. In Kenya, admissions to university and funding for attendance are determined by an individual’s score on a nationwide standardized exam, the Kenya Certificate of Secondary Education (KCSE) and a cutoff and placement determined by Kenya Universities and Colleges Central Placement Service (KUCCPS). In Pakistan the situation is slightly more complicated. Here, university-specific entrance exams are the primary determinants of admission. However, interviews and a few other criteria may also play a role after this initial cutoff determines whether applicants will be considered at all. To analyze the effect of “access” on each targeted outcome, we will use a regression of the outcome on an indicator for scoring above or below the requisite threshold as well as on the “forcing variable” (here, the test score). Key covariates, such as socio-demographic variables and pre-treatment measures of the given outcome variables, and other strong predictors will be included to increase precision. Given the nature of the admissions processes in Kenya and Pakistan, the RDD design is “fuzzy” for some common and some dissimilar reasons. That is, access does not have a one-to-one equivalency with attendance. Therefore, to address our secondary hypotheses about attendance, and when appropriate (that is, when the requisite IV assumptions hold), we will augment each of the standard RDD analyses described above with an instrumental variables (IV) approach. For these analyses, the instrument will be access (scoring above or below the requisite threshold) and the treatment variable will be actually enrolling in and attending the university in question. If we find that university access or attendance affects hope as well as subsequent attitudes and behaviors conducive to peace or conflict, we will also estimate the conditional association between hope and these future outcomes. These analyses are based purely on observational data and the assumptions required for the estimates to be interpreted causally are stronger than in our analyses. However, if we find statistically significant associations between hope (measured post-treatment) and these other outcomes, it would lend support to the hypothesis that this relationship is mediated by hope.

q27.value: RDD based on government (Kenya) and university (Pakistan) admissions decisions as treatment.

attributes.title: Changing Social Norms Via Local Radio

q1.value: Changing Social Norms Via Local Radio

q2.value: Donald Green | Dylan Groves | Constantine Manda

q5.value: The authors would like to thank the implementing partner, Uzikwasa, led ably by Vera Pieroth and Novatus Urassa with support from Kennedy Mashema, Mohammed Hanmie, Maimuna Msangi, Mariam Ally, Maajuba Ally, Kelvin Mpinga, Nickson Lutenda, Rehema Kilapilo, Joseph Peniel, Salvata Kalanga, Rajab Mustafa, Cosmas Clement, Steven Leonard, Kahawi Ally, Flora Byonta, Catherine Sekibaha, Ibrahim Mollel, Mtumwa Kombora, Sayuna Makasy, Philbert Mashingia, George Mchopa, Shaniel Temand, and Hamisi Makungu; the research team at Innovations for Poverty Action, including exceptional research coordination by Martin Zuakulu, project management by Rachel Jones and Country Director Rachel Steinacher, and field work by the IPA team led by Robert Mwandumbya and Gilbert Loshook; Shelley Lees, Bathsheba Mahenge, and Mark Marchant for thoughtful comments on the survey instrument and research design; and Anna Wilke, Jasper Cooper, Robert Fleishmann, Daniel Thomas, and Salif Jatieh for their invaluable help throughout the process. The authors are thankful for generous funding and support from the Wellspring Philanthropic Fund., This research was approved by Columbia University’s Institutional Review Board, protocol number: IRB-AAAR5582 and Tanzania’s Commission of Science and Technology (COSTECH), protocol number: 14528

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Many organizations use radio messages and programs to influence attitudes and norms around social issues. These programs are meant to improve social welfare by decreasing the social acceptability of anti-social behavior, such as early forced marriage and domestic violence. Even as media campaigns expand, there is a lack of rigorous evidence about the effect of real-world radio messages on social attitudes and behaviors. This project will provide a rigorous evaluation of the effects of progressive mass media on social attitudes and behaviors in Tanzania’s Tanga. We will assess the effects of messaging through community radio listening by randomly selecting communities to participate in village-level screenings of the radio soap opera Tamapendo, produced by the Tanzanian organization Uzikwasa to increase awareness of and proactive responses to early forced marriage and gender-based violence. To test the effect of the radio screenings, we will compare knowledge and attitudes in villages randomly selected to view the Uzikwasa-produced programs with attitudes in villages randomly selected for the placebo group (who listen to Wahapahapa, a popular radio soap opera focusing on stories involving treatment for HIV-AIDS) 8-10 days after the programs are shown.

q16.value: 1.1. Primary Hypotheses We expect to see the strongest treatment effects in the following areas: 1.1.1. Discussion We hypothesize that a larger proportion of respondents in each treatment group will report having discussed the topic of their village’s assigned treatment group. We will test the joint significance of two (one-sided) treatment effects (Wahapahapa screening on HIV/AIDS discussion, Tamapendo screening on early forced marriage). 1.1.2. Knowledge We hypothesize that a higher proportion of respondents in Wahapahapa assigned villages will be familiar with basic information regarding HIV treatment and transmission We do not anticipate changes in level of knowledge about early forced marriage or intimate partner violence in either group. 1.1.3. Conative Attitudes We hypothesize that a higher proportion of respondents will select actions aligned with norms advocated in the radio screenings: ● Wahapahapa: willingness to reveal HIV/AIDS status to friends and family and accept HIV/AIDS positive coworkers ● Tamapendo: supports girls resisting early forced marriage, willingness to report instances of early forced marriage to authorities 1.1.4. Conative Norms We hypothesize that higher proportion of respondents will report believing that other community members hold conative attitudes that align with the radio screening ● Wahapahapa: willingness to work alongside other HIV positive individuals ● Tamapapendo: willingness to report instances of early forced marriage to authorities, support for women resisting early forced marriage 1.2. Secondary Hypotheses We may observe treatment effects in the following areas: 1.2.1. Cognitive Attitudes We hypothesize that a higher proportion of respondents will report attitudes aligning with those espoused in the radio screening ● Wahapahpa: reduced stigma against HIV positive individuals ● Tampaendo: reduced support for early forced marriage, support for laws banning early forced marriage 1.2.2. Cognitive Norms We hypothesize that a higher proportion of respondents will report believe that their community’s attitudes align with those espoused in the radio screening ● Tamapendo: reduced support for early forced marriage 1.2.3. Priorities We hypothesize that a higher proportion of respondents will report that the topics highlighted in the screenings are community and electoral priorities. ● Tamapendo: votes for hypothetical candidate committed to reducing early forced marriage, lists reducing early forced marriage as a community priority ● Wahapahapa: vote for hypothetical candidate committed to improving access to hiv/aids treatment, lists HIV/AIDS as a community priority 1.3. Tertiary Hypotheses The following hypotheses are premised on the idea that radio dramas cause listeners to rethink their broad views about gender equality: 1.3.1. Intimate Partner Violence We hypothesize that respondents who listen to the Tamapendo screening will report more progressive cognitive and conative attitudes and norms related to intimate partner violence. ● Conative attitudes: willingness to report incidents of intimate partner violence, support for victims responding to intimate partner violence ● Conative norms: believes other community members would report intimate partner violence ● Cognitive attitudes: reduced acceptance of intimate partner violence in different situations ● Cognitive norms: believes other community members accept intimate partner violence 1.3.2. Gender Hierarchy We hypothesize that respondents who listen to the Tampaendo screening will report more progressive cognitive and conative attitudes related to gender hierarchy ● Cognitive attitudes: believes women earning more than men won’t cause problems, believes men and women should share household work equally, believes boys and girls should both go to school, believes girls can go to town for school or work ● Conative attitudes: increased support for allowing girls to migrate to town, increased support for providing financial support for girls to go to town

q17.value: Overview: One key feature of the design is cluster randomization: Screenings were held in 30 villages between July 25 and September 10th. Villages were blocked into 15 wards and randomly assigned to either Tamapendo (focusing on early forced marriage) or Wahapahapa (focusing on HIV/AIDS stigma). The other is sampling within clusters: In each of 40 randomly selected households in each village, one household member (20 men and 20 women) was invited to attend the radio drama screening. Screenings were typically held in the early afternoon, and in some cases again in the evening. Participants were invited to the screenings at the end of the baseline interview. They were told that the screenings would feature free refreshments, and the screenings were free of charge. They were not told about the content of the program. Randomization: The sampling process yielded 16 blocks (15 blocks for treatment / placebo and one for replacement) of 2 clusters each. We then randomly assigned Treatment and Placebo screening conditions within each pair. In the case that a village needed to be discarded, we specified that we would replace the village with the next village on the ward’s list of randomly ordered. We will conduct randomization after confirming two viable villages in a ward. In the case that the ward had no new villages meeting the criteria specified in Section 4.1, we would move to the replacement ward. Estimation: For all analyses, we will estimate treatment effects using least squares regression and clustered standard errors, with fixed effects for block (ward). Additional covariates will be selected using the process outlined in Section 4.

registration_responses.q1: Changing Social Norms Via Local Radio
registration_responses.q2: Donald Green | Dylan Groves | Constantine Manda

attributes.title: Understanding Corruption: Experimental Evidence from Africa

q1.value: Understanding Corruption: Experimental Evidence from Africa

q2.value: John A Doces | Donatien K Adou | Amy Wolaver

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In political science and economics, development in Africa and other parts of the developing world is seen as being constrained by problems of corruption. While the notion of corruption and its effects are seen in an objective way by scholars and policymakers in western countries, it is not clear that the same view is held by people living in the developing world. Two core questions guide this research: Who is likely to be corrupt? What is corrupt? Building on these questions, this research seeks to better understand (i) how people view corruption and who is corrupt (ii) what acts are thought to be corrupt (iii) if corruption rankings by Transparency International actually affect people’s decisions and (iv) if findings on trends about corruption are able to be replicated. Transparency International defines corruption as bribe taking for personal gain. While the taking of a bribe is indicative corrupt behavior there is much that is not clear about what exactly is corrupt. If one pays a bribe is that different than if one asks for a bribe? Moreover, does it matter is the bribe is ‘petty’ or ‘grand’? Finally, does it matter for what use the bribe is being committed? We test these questions in this project using an experimental analysis based on a conjoint analysis. In addition, we test research based on joint work by Transparency International and Afrobarometer testing questions about the extent of corruption and progress made fighting corruption. We will conduct our research in Senegal and Côte d’Ivoire.

q16.value: We test several hypotheses regarding different variables and forms of corruption: Gender H1: In comparing individuals, men are more likely to be viewed as corrupt compared to women. H1a. In comparing individuals, female respondents are less likely to view women as corrupt than men. H1b. In comparing individuals, male respondents are less likely to view women as corrupt than men. Education H2: In comparing individuals, those with education from western countries will be viewed as less corrupt than those with education from African countries. H3. In comparing individuals, those with education from former colonies will be viewed as more corrupt than those with education from other countries. Position H4. In comparing individuals, those with public position will be viewed as more corrupt than those with private positions. H5. In comparing individuals, religious leaders will be viewed as less corrupt than leaders holding all other positions. H6. In comparing individuals, traditional leaders will be viewed as less corrupt than leaders holding all other positions except religious leaders. Ethnicity and Religion H7. In comparing individuals, those sharing a common ethnic identity/religion will be less likely to claim corruption compared to those not sharing a common ethnic identity/religion. Corruption H8. In comparing individuals, those paying bribes will be seen as less corrupt compared to those demanding bribes. H9. In comparing individuals, those paying bribes for public gain will be seen as less corrupt than those paying bribes for personal gain. H10. In comparing individuals, those demanding bribes for public gain will be seen as less corrupt than those demanding bribes for personal gain. H11. In comparing individuals, those paying petty bribes will be seen as less corrupt than those paying grand bribes. H12. In comparing individuals, those demanding petty bribes will be seen as less corrupt than those demanding grand bribes. H13. In comparing individuals, those paying petty bribes will be seen as less corrupt than those demanding petty bribes. H14. In comparing individuals, those paying grand bribes will be seen as less corrupt than those demanding grand bribes. H15. In comparing individuals, those asked if their country’s corruption score from TI is accurate will be less likely to donate participation fee than those not asked the question.

q17.value: Survey experiment using a conjoint analysis.

registration_responses.q1: Understanding Corruption: Experimental Evidence from Africa
registration_responses.q2: John A Doces | Donatien K Adou | Amy Wolaver
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

In addition, we test research based on joint work by Transparency International and Afrobarometer testing questions about the extent of corruption and progress made fighting corruption. We will conduct our research in Senegal and Côte d’Ivoire.
registration_responses.q16: We test several hypotheses regarding different variables and forms of corruption: Gender H1: In comparing individuals, men are more likely to be viewed as corrupt compared to women. H1a. In comparing individuals, female respondents are less likely to view women as corrupt than men. H1b. In comparing individuals, male respondents are less likely to view women as corrupt than men. Education H2: In comparing individuals, those with education from western countries will be viewed as less corrupt than those with education from African countries. H3. In comparing individuals, those with education from former colonies will be viewed as more corrupt than those with education from other countries. Position H4. In comparing individuals, those with public position will be viewed as more corrupt than those with private positions. H5. In comparing individuals, religious leaders will be viewed as less corrupt than leaders holding all other positions. H6. In comparing individuals, traditional leaders will be viewed as less corrupt than leaders holding all other positions except religious leaders. Ethnicity and Religion H7. In comparing individuals, those sharing a common ethnic identity/religion will be less likely to claim corruption compared to those not sharing a common ethnic identity/religion. Corruption H8. In comparing individuals, those paying bribes will be seen as less corrupt compared to those demanding bribes. H9. In comparing individuals, those paying bribes for public gain will be seen as less corrupt than those paying bribes for personal gain. H10. In comparing individuals, those demanding bribes for public gain will be seen as less corrupt than those demanding bribes for personal gain. H11. In comparing individuals, those paying petty bribes will be seen as less corrupt than those paying grand bribes. H12. In comparing individuals, those demanding petty bribes will be seen as less corrupt than those demanding grand bribes. H13. In comparing individuals, those paying petty bribes will be seen as less corrupt than those demanding petty bribes. H14. In comparing individuals, those paying grand bribes will be seen as less corrupt than those demanding grand bribes. H15. In comparing individuals, those asked if their country’s corruption score from TI is accurate will be less likely to donate participation fee than those not asked the question.
registration_responses.q17: Survey experiment using a conjoint analysis.

attributes.title: Increasing Framing Effectiveness: The Importance of Identity Salience to Climate Change Attitudes and Behavior

q1.value: Increasing Framing Effectiveness: The Importance of Identity Salience to Climate Change Attitudes and Behavior

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study tests how an individual's salient identity may impact how they react to a political communication frame, particularly on highly polarizing issues. Research tells us that efforts to frame highly politically polarized issues (such as climate change) often fail because an individual's partisan identity is highly salient and drives his or her attitudes on the issue (Bernauer & McGrath, 2016; Hart & Nisbet, 2012; Zhou, 2016). Because climate change has become a cornerstone issue that defines what it means to identify as a Democrat or a Republican in the United States (Bliuc et al., 2015), any mention of climate change activates a partisan identity, leading to policy preferences that reflect that identity. By ignoring the interaction between identity salience (the aspect of an individual’s identity that is most likely to drive attitudes and preferences at a given time) and frame acceptance, policy communicators have overlooked an important factor that can determine the success or failure of climate change framing efforts. One way to increase concern about things that will happen far in the future (such as the impacts of climate change) is to activate an individuals’ identity as a parent. By bringing an individual’s identity as a parent to mind, priming a parental identity may lead them to consider the consequences of their actions and decisions on the welfare of their children and future generations. Encountering a frame about the impacts of climate change on future generations when an individual’s parental identity is salient, then, may increase the effectiveness of the framing effort and increase support for climate change mitigation policies. In this study, I experimentally test this theory through a survey experiment with parents. Through random treatment assignment, I test whether priming a parental identity before presenting a climate change frame increases support for climate change policies, compared to priming a partisan identity, only receiving the frame, or no treatment. Additionally, to understand how conflicting identities influence framing effectiveness, I also test how priming both a parental and a partisan identity changes an individual’s response to a climate change frame. This project adds to the literature by testing the role that identity salience plays in frame effectiveness, and well as understanding how individuals reconcile competing identity primes when evaluating climate change communication frames.

q16.value: 1. Priming a parental identity before presenting the frame will increase policy support for climate change policies, compared to the control group and the frame only group. 2. Priming a partisan identity before presenting the frame will increase policy support among Democrats, and decrease policy support among Republicans, compared to the control group and the frame only group. 3. Receiving a competing frame (priming parental and partisan identities) will have no significant impact on policy preferences compared to the control and the frame only groups.

q17.value: A randomized online survey experiment will be used, with participants from the Prolific online survey platform. Participants will be US adults that are also parents. The survey will involve five treatment groups, and participants will be randomly assigned to receive 1 of the following treatments: 1. A parental prime (a series of question about being a parent) + framing message about the impact of climate change on children 2. A partisan prime (a series of question about political identity) + framing message about the impact of climate change on children 3. A competing prime (a series of question about being a parent) + framing message about the impact of climate change on children 4. Framing message about the impact of climate change on children 5. No message (control) Following the treatment, participants will answer several outcome variable questions about their climate change attitudes and policy preferences.

attributes.title: Social Media Effects on News Credibility

q1.value: Social Media Effects on News Credibility

q5.value: We gratefully acknowledge support from the Dartmouth Center for the Advancement of Learning.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Many Americans get political news through social media. However, these platforms do not vet the content that appears on them for accuracy and credibility in the same way that news media sites do. We would like to know if content from social media sites is seen as less credible and if users’ concerns about content on social media are triggered when they see other clearly disreputable content. We expect that presenting dubious content will remind people of the controversy over low-quality content on Facebook, including the role of so-called “fake news” in the 2016 election. As a result, we expect that people will be more distrustful (either subconsciously or consciously) when they are subsequently read another article.

q16.value: We plan to test the following hypotheses.   Hypotheses:   H1: Platform effect – News articles seen on Facebook will be perceived as less credible than those which are not on Facebook. H2: Within-platform credibility spillovers – Seeing a low credibility article on a social media platform will reduce the perceived credibility of other articles on that platform relative to seeing a high credibility article.   We also plan to explore the following research question for which we do not have strong theoretical expectations:   RQ1: Does the manipulation of the credibility of an adjacent article on a platform affect respondents’ self-reported likelihood of reading an unrelated article, sending it to a friend, indicating you like it on Facebook, or sharing on Facebook? RQ2: Do the effects of the platform manipulation (H1) and the within-feed credibility manipulation (H2) on our primary outcome variables vary by respondents’ social media usage? RQ3: Does exposure to low credibility articles on social media diminish feelings of epistemic political efficacy? (EPE)

q17.value: [All of the survey items and the experimental protocol are attached below.]   Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants Participants will be U.S. residents age 18 or over are recruited from Amazon Mechanical Turk. We exclude Turk participants who previously took part in our pilot studies from our sample, but otherwise all U.S. adult Turkers with HIT approval rates over 95% are eligible. Overall, the sample size will be about n = 3000 participants.   Randomization approach We will use a between-subjects design in which respondents are randomly assigned to one of five conditions by the Qualtrics online survey platform (p=1/5 for each): -Target article, no platform -Target article, platform (Facebook) -Target article, platform + feed with placebo article -Target article, platform + feed with low credibility article -Target article, platform + feed with high credibility article   We also randomize target article order (we ask about two) and which manipulated article precedes the target article.   Data collection and blinding Respondents are anonymous to us – we collect data on the Qualtrics online survey platform and only observe the Turk IDs of our participants.   Primary and secondary outcome measures   Our primary outcome measures are ratings of the target article’s perceived accuracy, trustworthiness, bias, and credibility on a four-point scale. We will then measure whether these items form a reliable scale. If they items all scale together or if all but one item do, we will use a simple average for the qualifying items. If the items do not scale together, we will treat each as a separate outcome variable.   Each outcome measure below includes a blank space where we incorporated a summary description of the relevant item.   How accurate would you expect the article on ____ to be? Not at all accurate  (1) Not very accurate  (2) Somewhat accurate  (3) Very accurate  (4)   How trustworthy would you expect the article on ____  to be? Not at all trustworthy  (1) Not very trustworthy  (2) Somewhat trustworthy  (3) Very trustworthy  (4)   How credible would you expect the article on ____to be? Not at all credible  (1) Not very credible  (2) Somewhat credible  (3) Very credible (4)   How biased would you expect the article on _____ to be? Not at all biased  (1) Not very biased  (2) Somewhat biased  (3) Very biased  (4)   We will also consider other ways in people interact with articles after being exposed to them on social media as separate secondary outcome measures:   How likely is it that you would choose to read the article about ______? Not at all likely  (1) Not very likely  (2) Somewhat likely  (3) Very likely  (4)   How likely is it that you would choose to send the article about ______ to a friend? Not at all likely  (1) Not very likely  (2) Somewhat likely  (3) Very likely  (4)   How likely would you be to "like" the article about _____ if it appeared in your Facebook News Feed? [asked only of respondents who indicate they use Facebook and read their News Feed] Not at all likely  (1) Not very likely  (2) Somewhat likely  (3) Very likely  (4)   How likely would you be to "share" the article about _____ if it appeared in your Facebook News Feed? [asked only of respondents who indicate they use Facebook and read their News Feed] Not at all likely  (1) Not very likely  (2) Somewhat likely  (3) Very likely  (4)   Finally, we use epistemic political efficacy as a secondary outcome measure. We intend to use respondents’ average scores on this battery if the scale is reliable and the items scale together. Otherwise we will analyze these outcomes independently.   I feel confident that I can find the truth about political issues. Strongly agree (4) Somewhat agree (3) Somewhat disagree (2) Strongly disagree (1)   if I wanted to, I could figure out the facts behind most political disputes. Strongly agree (4) Somewhat agree (3) Somewhat disagree (2) Strongly disagree (1) There are objective facts behind most political disputes, and if you try hard enough you can find them. Strongly agree (4) Somewhat agree (3) Somewhat disagree (2) Strongly disagree (1)   Statistical analyses   If our outcome measures pool (see below), results will be estimated as stacked question-level data using OLS with target article fixed effects and robust standard errors clustered by respondent. These results will be verified for robustness using appropriate GLM estimators and by using respondent random effects (respondent fixed effects cannot be estimated due to multicollinearity). Unless otherwise noted, all experimental treatment effects will be estimated as intent to treat effects.   If the effects of key explanatory variables differ significantly depending on the target article, we will present separate models in the main text for expositional clarity and present interactive models in an appendix. We will estimate marginal effects as appropriate when interaction terms are included in our models.   Our primary analysis will consider the effects of our treatments.   Define target_cred as our composite outcome measure of perceived article credibility, platform as a variable that takes the value of 1 if the target article appears on Facebook and takes the value of 0 otherwise, and feed as a variable that takes the value of 1 if the target article appears as part of a simulated news feed and takes the value of 0 otherwise   We then estimate the following: reg target_cred platform if feed==0, robust [H1]   To test H2, we use the indicators low_cred and high_cred for those conditions. reg target_cred low_cred high_cred if feed==1, robust lincom high_cred-low_cred [H2]   To test RQ1, we estimate identical models to those above for our secondary platform outcome measures (read, send, like, share): foreach var of varlist read send like share { reg `var’ platform if feed==0, robust [RQ1] reg `var’ low_cred high_cred if feed==1, robust [RQ1] }   To test RQ2, we estimate the following: reg target_cred platform##low_social platform##high_social lincom platform#low_social-platform#high_social [RQ2]   reg target_cred low_cred##low_social##high_social high_cred##low_social##high_social if feed==1, robust (low_social#high_cred-low_social#high_cred)-(high_social#high_cred-high_social#low_cred) [RQ2]   where low_social and high_social are the top and bottom terciles on a measure of social media usage that is the average of questions measuring self-reported frequencies of general Facebook use and News Feed reading specifically.   Finally, we test RQ3 using the standard models for H2 described above but with our EPE measure as the outcome variable:   reg EPE low_cred high_cred if feed==1, robust lincom high_cred-low_cred [RQ3]   We will also measure respondent attention by computing scores on post-treatment questions testing recall of our target articles (means by condition and overall).   Finally, we will validate our low versus high credibility manipulation by asking respondents directly about them. Specifically, each of the manipulated articles will be tested using the same format above among those who saw them:   reg y high_cred, robust   where y=our scale of article credibility (constructed as described above) or individual questions about article credibility if the items don’t scale together.   In all cases above, we will assess our assumption that our treatment effects pool across stimuli and question order by testing whether there is no difference in treatment effects by question order, between versions of the low and high credibility articles, and between versions of the placebo content. If any of these assumptions are violated, we will estimate more elaborate models with additional interaction terms as appropriate, though we may include these more complex models in an appendix and report separate models in the main text for expositional purposes. We otherwise average over randomized factors that are not included in our models.   Notes: -We will compute and report appropriate auxiliary quantities from our models to test the hypotheses of interest, including marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from the models including interaction terms, treatment effects by subgroup, and differences in marginal effects between subgroups. -In some cases, we may present treatment effects estimated on different subsets of the data for expositional clarity. If so, we will verify that we can reject the null of no difference in treatment effects in a more complex interactive model reported in an appendix when possible. -For interaction terms, scales, and moderators, if results are consistent using a median/tercile split or indicators rather than a continuous scale, we may present the latter in the main text for ease of exposition and include the continuous scale results in an appendix. We will also use tercile indicators to test whether a linearity assumption holds for any interactions with continuous moderators per Hainmueller et al (N.d.) and replace any continuous interactions in our models with them if it does not. -Don’t know responses will be considered missing data for the factual belief outcome measures. -We will compute and report summary statistics for our samples. We will also collect and may report response timing data as a proxy for respondent attention. -The order of hypotheses and analyses in the final manuscript may be altered for expositional clarity. -Where applicable, regression results for binary dependent variables will be verified for robustness using probit. Regression results for individual ordered dependent variables will be verified for robustness using ordered probit. -We may estimate the experimental models described above with a standard set of covariates (indicators for gender, age groups, non-white respondents, respondents with a four-year college degree, and scores on a standard political knowledge scale) if including those has a substantively important effect on the precision of our treatment effect estimates. In that case, however, both models will be reported. - Participants’ political knowledge will be assessed with a standard five-question battery that test participant knowledge of U.S. electoral rules and awareness of current political figures. Partisanship is measured on a standard seven-point scale administered via branching questions.

q2.value: Sean Webeck | Sean Nicholson-Crotty | Jill Nicholson-Crotty

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Our interest in this project on the role of gender in the use of performance information among those who work in the public sector arose out of the findings of a previous experiment. The initial experiment was intended to be part of a dissertation project which seeks to understand how bureaucrats and public sector managers process performance information. We asked people to assess the performance of a public organization. In one round they were given a single piece of performance information about an unnamed public sector organization and asked to assess the overall performance of the city. In the next round we asked them to assess their own performance had they been in that position. While the purpose of that study was not to look at gender we found some intriguing results. But, because we did not intend to look for those results it made this an exploratory experiment for us. In order to be more transparent we wanted to properly pre-register a new version of the experiment and then rerun the experiment with some slight variations from the first time we ran the survey. Our pre-analysis plan describes this process in more detail.

q16.value: Does gender play a role in how public sector employees process performance information? Do females respond more strongly to negative stimuli than males? Do the effects of a negative stimuli change when one is asked to evaluate themselves versus something else (e.g., an organization for which they work?

q17.value: We will use ANOVA and other post-hoc assessment techniques to determine any differences in the assessed performance of individuals randomly assigned to different treatment groups.

registration_responses.q2: Sean Webeck | Sean Nicholson-Crotty | Jill Nicholson-Crotty
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: Our interest in this project on the role of gender in the use of performance information among those who work in the public sector arose out of the findings of a previous experiment. The initial experiment was intended to be part of a dissertation project which seeks to understand how bureaucrats and public sector managers process performance information. We asked people to assess the performance of a public organization. In one round they were given a single piece of performance information about an unnamed public sector organization and asked to assess the overall performance of the city. In the next round we asked them to assess their own performance had they been in that position. While the purpose of that study was not to look at gender we found some intriguing results. But, because we did not intend to look for those results it made this an exploratory experiment for us. In order to be more transparent we wanted to properly pre-register a new version of the experiment and then rerun the experiment with some slight variations from the first time we ran the survey. Our pre-analysis plan describes this process in more detail.
registration_responses.q16: Does gender play a role in how public sector employees process performance information? Do females respond more strongly to negative stimuli than males? Do the effects of a negative stimuli change when one is asked to evaluate themselves versus something else (e.g., an organization for which they work?
registration_responses.q17: We will use ANOVA and other post-hoc assessment techniques to determine any differences in the assessed performance of individuals randomly assigned to different treatment groups.

attributes.title: Do Voters Communicate Different Expectations to Female Politicians?

q1.value: Do Voters Communicate Different Expectations to Female Politicians?

q2.value: Daniel Butler | Elin Naurin | Patrik Öhberg

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: In this project we will collaborate with state legislators in the United States to see if women and men hear different messages from constituents regarding approval of their party and their expectations for what the legislator should do. We have successfully recruited a Republican legislative pair to work with and hope to recruit a Democratic legislative pair. The politicians we partner with will send out letters to a randomly chosen sample of citizens, asking for their input via a survey. Some citizens will be asked for input from a female politician and some will be asked for input by a male politician. The politicians will be collecting input on voter approval of their party and also a list of what voters want them to work on.

q16.value: Greater Expectations for Women Hypothesis. Voters tell female politicians to work on more issues than they tell men to work on. Lower Approval for Women Hypothesis. Voters tell female politicians (in comparison to male politicians) that they are less satisfied with their party. This will be tested with an ordered logit regression.

q17.value: Greater Expectations for Women Hypothesis. Voters will be asked for the issues they think the legislator should work on. RAs will blind code their open-ended responses to get the number of issues mentioned. This will be the DV. An OLS regression will estimate the treatment effect. Lower Approval for Women Hypothesis. Voters will be asked about how much they approve of their party. A ordered logit regression will be used to estimate the treatment effect.

q19.value: 2,000 if both partners come through (500 from the Republican pair and 1,500 from the Democratic pair)

attributes.title: Partnership with Organizations focused on Women’s Issues for Rigorous Impact Evaluation: An Email Experiment with NGO’s in India

q1.value: Partnership with Organizations focused on Women’s Issues for Rigorous Impact Evaluation: An Email Experiment with NGO’s in India

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Women in India face many disadvantages and targeted suppression and violence, including poverty, lack of education, trafficking, and sexual assault. Policy makers work to address these issues, but often policy change is not enough. Many non-governmental organizations (NGO’s) in India work to supplement the gap between policy and practice by addressing these issues through direct assistance in their communities. While we assume that these organizations have good intent in their efforts to assist and empower women, many are not as effective as they could be, and some end up unknowingly adversely impacting their communities. Rigorous impact evaluation of an organization’s program can inform NGO’s on how effective their approach is, and what they can do to increase their positive impact. Impact evaluation involves implementing a randomized control trial, in which one group of people is randomly assigned to participate in the program and is compared to a control group that does not participate. Evaluators use this method to pinpoint the actual impact of the program, and determine what the impact of the intervention is, whether the intervention has a positive or negative effect, and what can be done to improve the effectiveness of the intervention or program. While this is a useful method to maximize the positive impacts of NGO’s in their community, the organization of course has to agree to the evaluation, which often places demands on their limited resources. This study works to understand the factors that make NGO’s more likely to agree to a partnership with an evaluator based on different treatments. These treatment effects are evaluated through a randomized control trial with a factorial treatment design, where emails with the treatment effects are sent to NGO’s that are focused on women’s issues in India. We plan to evaluate how the treatments affect the likelihood that an NGO would agree to a partnership, along with their access to and willingness to provide funds and resources necessary for the evaluation.

q16.value: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the impact of the three treatment arms (described above) on the likelihood of a women’s NGO expressing interest in an evaluation, and subsequently in their willingness to provide the resources to implement the impact evaluation, in order to improve future efforts to evaluate NGO’s focused on women. We will test the following hypotheses: 1. The emotional language treatment will elicit greater interest in impact evaluation partnership than the factual language treatment. 2. Both the donor attractiveness and the participatory approach treatments will elicit greater interest in impact evaluation partnership than the placebo approach. 2a. Donor attractiveness will elicit greater interest than the participatory approach treatment. 3. NGO’s that receive emails from the female contactor will be more likely to express interest in impact evaluation partnership than those emailed by the male contactor. We measure the take up rates for rigorous impact evaluation. The outcome measures will be estimated and compared based on the three treatment arms. Our outcome measures for each of the hypotheses are (respectively): Expression of interest in impact evaluation from NGO and Willingness to fund or search for funding for the impact evaluation, given an original expression of interest from the NGO

q17.value: We will use a Bayesian approach to our analyses by setting prior distributions for the regression parameters. We will implement a Bayesian approach to estimate both the average treatment effects (ATE) and to run binomial regression in order to estimate the likelihood of an NGO expressing interest, based on the results of the previous study. We also plan to implement a Bayesian approach in a two-stage regression analysis to evaluate the impact of our treatments on the likelihood that an NGO will be willing to provide the funding and resources, given that they have already expressed an interest in an evaluation partnership. Two-stage analysis will be used to estimate the complier average causal effect (CACE) or treatment on treated. These analyses will be performed both for the two blocks individually (NGO’s directly focused on women and NGO’s focused on issues that impact women), and for the total dataset collectively. We will additionally report the uncertainty estimates in the regression analysis results and the credible intervals for the difference of means treatment effects, with an updated significance level that is calculated from a family wise error rate (FWER) adjustment to account for the multiple comparisons.

q19.value: 1400 in First Round, Unsure of Sample Size in Second Round

attributes.title: When do Elected Officials Seek Out Policy Expertise?

q1.value: When do Elected Officials Seek Out Policy Expertise?

q2.value: John McAndrews | Peter Loewen | Daniel Rubenson

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Successful policy making—and effective representation—requires policy knowledge, but legislators are typically policy generalists. This raises the question: when do MPs seek out policy expertise? In this project, we hypothesize that Canadian MPs are motivated to obtain policy knowledge when their party’s position differs from that of their constituency.

q16.value: 1A: MPs/their staff are more likely to seek out additional policy information if the preferences of their constituents differ from the policy of their party. 1B: The relationship described in 1A will be stronger among those MP/staff that are informed about the preferences of their consitutents.

q17.value: We have made available, through a Qualtrics survey, a video recording and written summary of an expert webinar on energy policy in Canada. We will invite by email Canadian MPs and their staff to access this recording and summary. We will randomly assign half of MPs to receive detailed information about the preferences of their constituents on energy policy—which we will provide to this treatment group as part of the invitation.
